coredata.dc:title: Application of a cost-effective boron-based electrolyte additive in high-voltage lithium metal battery

coredata.dc:description: Due to long-term operation under high voltage, the cathode of lithium metal battery undergoes parasitic reactions with the electrolyte, resulting in non-conductive polymers that severely affect the battery's electrochemical performance and kinetics. In addition, the safety performance of the battery is seriously compromised by severe lithium deposition on the lithium metal side. The use of electrolyte additives is one of the most cost-effective strategies for improvement. A low-cost boron-based additive bis(pinacolato)diboron (BDB) has been proposed in this work which has relatively high activity during battery charging and discharging. A protective cathode electrolyte interface (CEI) film was formed by BDB on the surface of NCM811 in advance to resist HF and solvent erosion. Furthermore, the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film that BDB participates in on the lithium metal surface exhibits high ion conductivity and effectively inhibits the formation of lithium dendrites, thereby ensuring the safe operation of lithium metal batteries. The lithium metal battery utilizing BDB not only exhibits optimal electrochemical performance with a high cut-off voltage of 4.6 V, but also demonstrates potential for further development in the realms of rapid charging and discharging.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Cycling performance of battery with electrolyte containing x% BDB between 2.8 and 4.5 V (a) and 2.8–4.6 V (c). Rate test result of the battery with different electrolytes (b). The selected charge-discharge voltage curves of battery with the baseline electrolyte (d) and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (e) during the 300 cycles. The voltage profiles of different batteries at 50 % SOC and 50 % DOC state (f). The Li+ diffusion coefficients of different batteries after the 1st (g) and 50th (h) cycle measured by GITT. Cycling performance of battery with different electrolytes at 5C between 2.8 and 4.5 V (i).

The HOMO energy levels of the solvents EC, DEC and BDB (a), binding energy with Li+ (b) and HF (c) of solvents and BDB, respectively. LSV curves of battery with different electrolytes (d). The CV profiles of Li/Cu half batteries were scanned at 0.1 mV s−1 over the potential range of 0.005 to 3.0 V (e). CV curves of batteries with different cycles using 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (f) and baseline electrolyte (i). 19F NMR result of the baseline (g) and 0.7 % BDB-containing electrolytes (h).

EIS curves of battery in pristine (a), 50th (b), 100th (d), and 150th (e) cycles. Bar chart of fitting values for different cycle numbers Rfilm (c) and Rct (f). Schematic diagram of NCM811 particles in different electrolytes (g). EIS equivalent circuit diagram (h).

Tafel plot for Li plating/stripping of the Li/Li battery in pristine (a) and 100th (b) state. Exchange current values of batteries with different cycles (c). EIS curves of the Li/Li symmetric system in pristine (d) and 100th (e) state. Rct and Rfilm values of batteries with different cycles (f). Modified Aurbach's measurement Li/Cu battery with different electrolyte (g). Long cycle performance of Li/Li battery with different electrolytes (h). Enlarged 50–70 h stage voltage-time profiles (i).

TEM of NCM811 cathode after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte (a) and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (g). HRTEM of NCM811 cathode after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte (d) and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (j). XPS characterization of NCM811 cathode after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte (b–c, e–f) and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (h–i, k–l). Possible mechanisms of action of BDB (m).

SEM of lithium metal anode after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte (a, d) and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (g, j). XPS characterization of lithium metal anode after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte (b–c, e–f) and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte (h–i, k–l).

head.ce:title: Application of a cost-effective boron-based electrolyte additive in high-voltage lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Due to long-term operation under high voltage, the cathode of lithium metal battery undergoes parasitic reactions with the electrolyte, resulting in non-conductive polymers that severely affect the battery's electrochemical performance and kinetics. In addition, the safety performance of the battery is seriously compromised by severe lithium deposition on the lithium metal side. The use of electrolyte additives is one of the most cost-effective strategies for improvement. A low-cost boron-based additive bis(pinacolato)diboron (BDB) has been proposed in this work which has relatively high activity during battery charging and discharging. A protective cathode electrolyte interface (CEI) film was formed by BDB on the surface of NCM811 in advance to resist HF and solvent erosion. Furthermore, the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film that BDB participates in on the lithium metal surface exhibits high ion conductivity and effectively inhibits the formation of lithium dendrites, thereby ensuring the safe operation of lithium metal batteries. The lithium metal battery utilizing BDB not only exhibits optimal electrochemical performance with a high cut-off voltage of 4.6 V, but also demonstrates potential for further development in the realms of rapid charging and discharging.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: As the popularity and market penetration of 3C (computer, communication, and consumer electronics) products has grown, so has the specific energy of battery products. The enhancement of specific energy is frequently attributed to the positive electrode component of the battery, for the same type of positive electrode, increasing the cut-off voltage is one method among the most effective ways to increase the discharge capacity [1–3]. After the attention garnered by LiFePO₄, high nickel ternary materials have been the subject of considerable interest due to the exemplary high-capacity characteristics, with LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) exhibiting particularly noteworthy performance. However, some problems have been found as the research deepens. The high-valence metal ions such as Ni4+, Mn4+ in NCM811 will catalyze the decomposition of the electrolyte as the cut-off voltage is increased (>4.3 V) [4–6]. Thereby more non-conductive polymer by-products are generated, which affect the electrochemical performance of the battery. At the same time, as the cycle continues for a long time, this problem will become more seriously.

The utilization of additives in the electrolyte is an efficacious and cost-effective methodology. The additives used can react in advance to form a kind of film on the electrode surface, thus preventing the electrolyte from contacting the electrode surface. A variety of electrolyte additives are available, including those containing silicon [7], nitrile fluorine groups [8,9], acrylonitrile [10], and phosphine-containing [11,12] additives. In recent years, boron-based additives have been the subject of extensive research due to their unique electron-deficient properties. As the only non-metallic element in the third main group, the valence electron structure is 2S22P1, which results in boron having electrophilic properties. Therefore, boron tends to form covalent bonds with electron-rich elements such as F and is stable due to the lack of electrons in the corresponding orbit [13–15]. At the same time, additives containing boron have also shown excellent performance in improving the performance of high-voltage battery. For example, Zheng's group previously reported that triisopropanolamine cyclic borate exhibits excellent performance in modifying high-voltage electrolytes. The CEI film formed by the compound not only absorbs hydrofluoric acid (HF) for protection but also enhances the battery's electrochemical performance [16]. Furthermore, Zhang et al. reported an organic boron-based additive that enhances the capacity retention rate to 93 % & 200 cycles as a consequence of the formation of a CEI film that can inhibit the leaching of high-valence metal ions [17]. Xiao et al. suggested that trimethylene borate performs excellently with a cut-off voltage of 4.5 V, which can protect the cathode by suppressing solvent decomposition. Finally, the capacity retention rate was 91 % after 200 cycles [18].

Here, we proposed a highly cost-effective boron-based additive BDB. Although its price is the lowest compared to boron-based additives that have emerged in recent years as shown in Table S1, its performance is excellent, and there have been almost no reports on its use in electrolyte modification before. The CEI film constructed by BDB advanced oxidation not only resists erosion from solvents and HF but also be an excellent ion conductor that facilitates the passage of lithium ions. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that incorporating BDB can mitigate the uneven deposition of lithium on the anode through lithium plating/striping testing, which is beneficial in enhancing the safety and stability of the battery. Therefore, the incorporation of BDB has been demonstrated to improve the electrochemical performance of the battery markedly. The capacity retention rate of the NCM811/Li battery with 0.7 % BDB reaches 85 % within the voltage range of 2.8–4.5 V in 300 cycles, along with the cycle retention rate of 76.5 % at 2.8–4.6 V in 200 cycles. What is more, the battery with BDB exhibited encouraging performance in high-rate current testing at 5C, exhibiting a nearly 20 % increase in capacity retention compared to the baseline electrolyte.

The cathode electrode is composed of active material NCM811 (purchased from Suzhou Jiade Energy Technology Co., Ltd), binder poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF, provided by Guangzhou Songbai Chemical Co., Ltd), and conductive agent carbon black, with a ratio of 8:1:1. An appropriate amount of solvent N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) was added to the three components to form a homogeneous state and coat the slurry on the surface of aluminum foil. Subsequently, the aluminum foil should be placed in an oven maintained at 80 °C under vacuum for a period of 10 h. Finally, the material load on the aluminum foil is 3–4 mg cm−2. 1 M LiPF6 in EC: DEC (1:1, v:v, purchased from Duoduo Chemical Reagents) was selected as baseline electrolyte. BDB (purity ≥98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., different content of BDB was added to baseline electrolyte, meanwhile, these modification electrolytes were named as x% BDB (x = 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9, 1.1).

The CR2025 coin-type battery in this work was composed of NCM811 electrode as the cathode, lithium metal electrode as the anode, and celgard 2325 separator. The assembly of the battery, as well as the storage of the electrolyte and electrodes, were carried out in the glove box filled with high-purity argon gas atmosphere (O2 < 0.01 ppm, H2O < 0.01 ppm).

The galvanostatic long cycle charge-discharge test was conducted on the LAND system (CT 2001 A, Wuhan, China), and the test voltage range in this work were 2.8–4.5 V and 2.8–4.6 V. The battery was activated for one cycle at a current density of 0.2C, followed by a long cycle test of charging at 0.5C and discharging at 1C. Rate testing and high current testing (5C) were also carried out on the LAND system. CHI440C electrochemical workstation was used for various electrochemical characterizations in battery systems, such as linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), cyclic voltammetry (CV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and Tafel curve. In situ tests at 105 Hz to 10−2 Hz and an amplitude of 5 mV were carried out on Solartron 1260/1287. The LSV was conducted among voltage range of 3–5 V with 0.1 mV s−1 sweep rate in Li/Al system. Different cycles EIS were measured from 105 Hz to 10−2 Hz at 5 mV amplitude. And then, CV curves were obtained on the basis that the test voltage range is 2.8–4.6 V at 0.1 mV s−1 sweep rate. Modified Aurbach's method was conducted as follows. Firstly, the Li/Cu battery was discharged at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 for 10 h, and then, charged until 1 V at 0.1 mA cm−2. Secondly, discharged at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 for 10 h again. Thirdly, The Li/Cu battery underwent 10 cycles with a charging and discharging current of 0.1 mA cm−2 and the lasting time is 1 h every step, finally, charged to 1 V at 0.1 mA cm−2. The Tafel curves were conducted with 0.5 mV s−1 scan rate (−0.2–0.2 V). The Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) charge-discharge current was 0.2C with the lasting time was 20 min among voltage range was 2.8–4.5 V, and then, every step relaxation time was 2 h.

Disassemble the battery in the glove box and wash away residual electrolyte on the surface of the electrode pieces with DMC solvent. The microstructure and interface structure of different sample surfaces are characterized by SEM (SU8010) and HRTEM (Talos F200X G2), respectively. Sample surface composition analysis is by means of XPS (ESCALAB 250Xi). In addition, the changes in the crystal structure of various samples are studied using XRD (Empyrean, PANalytical B. V, Netherlands). All samples must be transferred in a sealed container filled with high-purity argon gas (purity≥99.999 %) to avoid contact with air. NMR (BRUKER AVANCE NEO 400 MHz) is used to check the F spectrum information of two electrolytes after the addition of 1000 ppm water and standing for 2 days.

All theoretical calculations were based on the density functional theory (DFT). The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy level and binding energy in this paper were obtained by the B3LYP function in Gaussian 09 software. The algorithm 6–311 + G (d, p) was applied. First, the constructed model structure be optimized and then the molecular energy calculation was carried out to obtain the following results. Eq. (1) can be used to calculate the binding energies of different substances.

As shown in Fig. 1a, the effect of different contents of BDB on the electrochemical performance of NCM811/Li battery under cut-off voltage 4.5 V at 0.5/1C was tested. The discharge capacity of the battery with the modified electrolyte containing BDB was superior to that of the baseline electrolyte as performed in Table S2, and the discharge capacity is best when the BDB content is 0.7 %. Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 1b, the battery with electrolyte containing 0.7 % BDB exhibit superior performance based on the results of a rate test. Similarly, the battery with 0.7 % BDB demonstrates remarkable electrochemical performance at a higher cut-off voltage of 4.6 V, exhibiting a cycle retention rate of 75.98 % (Fig. 1c), however, the cycle retention rate of the battery with baseline electrolyte was only 54.94 %. Fig. 1d, e illustrates the uniformly selected charge-discharge voltage profiles of batteries with different electrolyte during 300 cycles. As the charging and discharging process continues, the charging platform in Fig. 1d significantly increases and the discharging platform also dramatically decreases, indicating a significant increase in polarization of the battery using the base electrolyte [19]. The same situation also appeared in the dQ/dV-V curves (Fig. S1a), where the peaks in the battery using the baseline electrolyte showed a trend of disorder and extremely low overlap. The combination of Figs. 1e and S1b provides assurance that the additive BDB can effectively suppress the occurrence of internal polarization in the battery. Furthermore, the voltage platform undergoes minimal changes with long-term charge-discharge cycles of the battery. Additionally, the selected dQ/dV-V curves exhibit a high degree of coincidence, which indicates that the battery has excellent reversibility. As illustrated in Fig. 1f, the 50 % state of charge (SOC) and depth of discharge (DOC) voltages of batteries with different electrolytes was further reveal changes that are easily overlooked, and also further support the above conclusion, indicating that the decrease in battery polarization may be related to the modified CEI film and SEI film formed by BDB, which is more conducive to maintaining the electrode crystal structure and reducing the occurrence of electrode surface side reactions. The GITT test has been used for the determination of the diffusion coefficient of Li+ in battery. (Fig. S2), which was fitted using the ECbox software based on Formula (1).

The Li+ diffusion coefficients of the battery in both the initial state and after 50 cycles were calculated. As shown in Fig. 1g, h, it was obviously that the ion diffusion coefficients of the battery with BDB added in both states were prior to the use of the baseline electrolyte, indicating that the CEI and SEI films formed by BDB has excellent ion conductivity. At the same time, the discharge performance of the two batteries was tested at a high current density of 5C. The result shown in Fig. 1i indicates that the battery's rapid charge-discharge performance improved due to the addition of BDB. The improvement may be attributed to BDB's formation of highly conductive CEI and SEI films.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of BDB on the NCM811 cathode and lithium metal
ce:section.ce:para: The order of molecular oxidation in a system could be reflected by the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of the molecule obtained by DFT. The values of the HOMO energy level shown in Fig. 2a indicate that BDB could undergo oxidation reactions in front of the EC and DEC, which the HOMO level of BDB is −7.15632 eV is larger than that of solvent molecules.

The LSV test results further confirmed this conclusion and a small oxidation peak at 3.83 V can be clearly observed in the Fig. 2d. The antioxidant potential of the system containing BDB increased by about 0.25 V, which is beneficial for the early oxidation of BDB. Meanwhile, the CV curve of the Li/Cu system containing BDB shows a reduction peak at around 1.5 V that does not appear in the baseline electrolyte system, indicating that BDB has a certain degree of reducibility in the system [20]. The above simulation and test results suggest that the additive of BDB maybe not only oxidize in advance to form CEI film at the cathode, but also participate in the formation of SEI film at the anode [21]. In the chronoamperometry tests at 4.8 V with a 12 h holding time with batteries after 0.2C cycles between 2.8 and 4.5 V (Fig. S3), the leakage current of the battery with BDB was always less than that of the battery with baseline electrolyte, indicating that the CEI and SEI films formed by BDB on the electrode surface have higher oxidation resistance [22]. Multi-level CV was utilized to test the stability of systems containing different electrolytes. After cycling for 5 cycles at a scanning speed of 0.2 mV S−1, the CV curve profiles of different cycles containing BDB system almost perfectly matched (Fig. S4a). In sharp contrast, the CV curve containing the basic electrolyte system appears a little disorganized (Fig. S4b). In addition, as presented in Fig. 2f, a, the selected number of CV cycles at a scanning speed of 0.1 mV S−1 also confirms the stability of the containing BDB system, which may be attributed to the stable CEI film formed by BDB. In addition, BDB has higher binding energy (121.913 kJ mol−1) with Li+ than EC-Li+ (84.06 kJ mol−1) and DECLi+ (72.54 kJ mol−1), indicating that BDB has a higher coordination tendency with lithium ions, which may be attributed to the matter that BDB has more coordination bonds with Li+. Furthermore, the higher initial coefficient efficiency (ICE) (Fig. S5) of the battery with 0.7 % BDB electrolyte suggests that some BDB contribute to the formation of CEI film at the cathode surface, while others form BDB-Li+ with Li+ and transfer to the anode side, participating in reduction reactions on its surface. The defense mechanism of HF plays a vital role in the management of battery health. As illustrated in Fig. 2c, BDB exhibits a greater binding energy with HF in comparison to EC and DEC, thereby indicating that BDB is more effective in restraining HF and preventing its facile escape. The result was further confirmed by 19F NMR testing. When 1000 ppm water was added to both electrolytes and stored at room temperature for two days, HF had already appeared in the baseline electrolyte. However, no peaks of HF were detected in the BDB electrolyte (Fig. 2g, h).

EIS is an important part of battery research due to the close relationship between battery dynamics, electrochemical performance and EIS values [23]. As shown in Fig. 3 , EIS of batteries with baseline electrolyte and 0.7 % BDB electrolyte in different cycles were tested. The EIS value of the pristine battery was simulated using the equivalent circuit 1 in Fig. 3h, where Rct represents the charge transfer impedance inside the electrode and W1 represents the Warburg induction. The Rct value of battery with 0.7 % BDB is smaller than the battery baseline electrolyte (Fig. 3c), indicating that the addition of BDB is beneficial for the discharge specific capacity of 1st cycle [23]. Fig. 3a, b, and d show the EIS curves of batteries with different electrolytes after the 50th, 100th, and 150th cycling, respectively. The EIS of the working battery was conducted using equivalent circuit 2, where Rfilm reflects the interface impedance between the electrode and the electrolyte. The values of Rfilm and Rct are shown in Fig. 3c, f, respectively. The Rfilm and Rct of the battery with baseline electrolyte increase rapidly as the battery operating time increases, indicating that parasitic reactions continue to occur on the electrode surface, leading to an increase in Rfilm and more severe erosion inside the electrode. However, the values of Rfilm in 0.7 % BDB electrolyte tend to stabilize after a slow increase, indicating that the high stability of the CEI film formed by BDB could effectively protect the electrode and has high ionic conductivity, which is consistent with the above conclusion (Fig. 1g, h). The result was further validated by means of SEM and XRD characterization. As illustrated in Fig. S6b, it can be observed that the surface cracks of NCM811 particles considerably increased after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte, whereas the rise in surface cracks of NCM811 particles in 0.7 % BDB electrolyte was not significant (Fig. S6d). Furthermore, a notable shift in the cathode crystal plane of NCM811 particles was observed after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte. However, the problem of deviation was significantly improved with an increase in BDB content (Fig. S7). In situ EIS was employed to further investigate the impedance changes of batteries during charging and discharging processes in different electrolytes (Fig. S8). Although the changes in in-situ EIS between the two batteries with different electrolytes during the initial cycle are not significant, there is a strong contrast in the in-situ EIS of the battery after 50 cycles. The impedance values of the battery cycled with 0.7 % BDB electrolyte are lower than those of the baseline electrolyte, and the symmetry of all EIS curves is better, indicating that the battery with 0.7 % BDB has high reversibility and fewer polarization phenomena [24].

The stability of lithium metal is of significant importance with regard to the dynamics and safety of batteries. The electrochemical kinetics of lithium in lithium metal batteries can be reflected through the Tafel curve and the EIS test as shown in Fig. 4a–f. The exchange current value of the battery with baseline electrolyte is lower than that of battery with 0.7 % BDB electrolyte, whether the battery is in its pristine state or after 100 cycles, suggesting less polarization phenomenon and higher ion transport performance in battery [25]. Meanwhile, the differences in the impact of the two electrolytes on the battery were further highlighted by the EIS tests. The Rfilm of the Li/Li battery with 0.7 % BDB was weaker than that of the battery with baseline electrolyte after 100 cycles in Fig. 4f, indicating that BDB is beneficial for the construction of SEI films with higher ionic conductivity and effectively reduces the side reactions, which is very consistent with the Tafel result. Li/Cu and Li/Li batteries were assembled to detect the reversibility of plating/stripping processes of Li+ in the battery. As demonstrated in Fig. 4g, the Li/Cu battery with 0.7 % BDB exhibits ultra-high CE relative to the baseline electrolyte by modified Aurbach's method. In addition, the voltage of Li/Li battery tends to stabilize overall over long cycling, and the polarization voltage of the battery containing BDB is lower than that of the battery with baseline electrolyte as depicted in Fig. 4i. However, the battery with baseline electrolyte begins to polarize severely after about 70 h, possibly due to a severe parasitic reaction between the solvent and the lithium metal, leading to a gradual depletion of the electrolyte. The above results confirm that BDB can effectively modified the polarization in battery through the formation of an SEI film with a high Li+ flux [26,27].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cathode and anode interface composition analysis
ce:section.ce:para: The morphology of the CEI film on the cathode surface was characterized by TEM. A comparison of Fig. 5a and g reveals that the CEI film formed by BDB is distributed uniformly on the surface of NCM811, with a thickness of approximately 2 nm. However, the NCM811 cathode exhibited significant unevenness in the CEI film thickness on its surface after 150 cycles in the baseline electrolyte, which affects the cathode surface protection mechanism. Moreover, too thick CEI film will affect Li+ transport and reduce the dynamic performance of the battery. HRTEM further demonstrates the existence of lattice discrepancies in NCM811 after 150 cycles in two electrolytes. As illustrated in Fig. 5d, the partial collapse and disorder of the NCM811 lattice may have a detrimental impact on the electrochemical performance of the battery. Conversely, the overall arrangement of the NCM811 lattice after cycling in the modified electrolyte was observed to be neat, which can be attributed to the protective mechanism of the CEI film formed by BDB on the surface (Fig. 5j). The compositional analysis of the CEI film on the cathode surface was conducted by XPS. The C 1s spectrum exhibited four distinct peaks, corresponding to the following chemical bonds: CC (284.8 eV), CO (286.8 eV), CO (289.0 eV), and CF (290.9 eV), the peaks of CO and CO are derived from the decomposition products ROCO2Li, ROLi, and Li2CO3 of the solvent [28]. As illustrated in Fig. 5b and h, the intensities of the two NCM811 peaks in the baseline electrolyte are greater than those in the 0.7 % BDB electrolyte, suggesting that CEI formed by BDB could effectively inhibit the decomposition of solvents on the cathode surface. Similarly, the content of CO and CO3 2− in 0.7 % BDB electrolyte are lower baseline electrolyte in the spectra of O 1 s, in addition, there is also an additional BO peak (531.8 eV) associated with BDB in Fig. 5i [29]. The weaker LiF peak may originate from the decomposition product of LiPO6 in the thinner CEI film formed by BDB (Fig. 5k). Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 5f, l, peaks Li-B-O (191.8 eV) and BF (194.2 eV) were also observed in the NCM811 sample in the modified electrolyte, which was absent in the other samples [29], indicating that BDB underwent oxidation at the surface of the cathode. At the same time, as shown by the binding energy results in Fig. 5m, BDB has a tendency to bind HF and EC, resulting in the formation of a compound CEI film containing B-O/B-F bases.

The stability of the lithium metal anode is of vital importance with regard to the safety of the lithium metal battery [30]. The formation of lithium dendrites on the surface of the lithium metal after 150 cycles in different electrolytes was compared by means of SEM, and the composition of the SEI film on the surface of the lithium metal was also analyzed by XPS. As illustrated in Fig. 6a, d, the built-in digital photograph demonstrates that the lithium metal surface was covered with dead lithium layers. The SEM of the lithium metal sample revealed the presence of dense lithium dendrites, which may have resulted in the potential formation of a micro short circuit through separator and cathode contact. However, as shown in the built-in digital photograph of Fig. 6g, the surface of lithium metal in 0.7 % BDB electrolyte only shows a small amount of dead lithium and the lithium metal surface is still clearly visible. Additionally, the SEM of Fig. 6g, j illustrate that the surface is smooth and devoid of lithium dendrites. The O 1s spectrum exhibited three peaks at 531.9 eV, 533.8 eV, and 528.3 eV, which were identified as belonging to CO, CO, and Li2O, respectively. However, Li2O was not included in Fig. 6b, which is an effective SEI component that helps to prevent HF erosion of the lithium metal due to its highly susceptible nature to HF and H₂O [31]. In addition, the LiF content that facilitates lithium-ion transport in the Fig. 6i is higher than that in the Fig. 6c. In P 2p spectrum, the peak intensity of LixPFyOz from LiPF6 decomposition has strong contrast in the Fig. 6e and k, lower peak intensity means that the SEI film can effectively prevent the decomposition of LiPF6 [32]. As illustrated in Fig. 6i, the BF peak (194.2 eV) may originate from compounds formed by BDB blocking the formation of HF. The above results demonstrate that the SEI film formed by BDB is beneficial for the uniform deposition of lithium ions and can effectively suppress the erosion of the anode by HF and solvents.

In summary, a low-cost and highly active boron-based additive was proposed for the first time in this work. The CEI film formed on the cathode surface and the SEI film formed on the anode surface have high ionic conductivity due to rich BO and LiF content, which is beneficial for improving the fast-charging performance of the battery. In addition, the film can effectively prevent further corrosion of the electrode by HF and solvents, resulting in an overall improvement in the electrochemical performance of the battery. The cycle retention rate of the NCM811/Li battery with 0.7 % BDB is 85 % at a cut-off voltage of 4.5 V after 300 cycles, what is more, the capacity retention rate is 76.5 % when the cut-off voltage is increased to 4.6 V after 200 cycles. In contrast, the NCM811/Li battery with baseline electrolyte cycle retention rate is only about 54 %.
Jian Lv: Writing – original draft, Resources, Methodology. Zhuyu Wang: Conceptualization. Yihuan Zhou: Formal analysis. Weihao Yu: Data curation. Qinggong Jia: Investigation.
